subsection.title: Addition and Multiplication
subsection.p: If you add together three or more numbers, such as 2+5+8 it doesn't matter which addition you do first; you will get the same answer either way.

ol.label: a

subsection.p: These two facts illustrate the associative laws for addition and multiplication.

assemblage.title: Associative Law for Addition
assemblage.p: If a, b and c are any numbers, then (a+b)+c = a+(b+c)

assemblage.title: Associative Law for Multiplication
assemblage.p: If a, b and c are any numbers, then (a \cdot b) \cdot c = a \cdot (b \cdot c)

subsection.title: Subtraction and Division
subsection.p: What about a string of subtractions or a string of divisions, such as 20-8-5~~~~~~~~~~\text{or}~~~~~~~~~~36 \div 6 \div 2 In these calculations, we get different answers, depending on which operations we perform first, as you can see in Example 2.

assemblage.p: The associative laws do not hold for subtraction or division.

subsection.p: So, if there are no parentheses in the expression, how do we know which operations to perform first?

ol.li: In a string of additions and subtractions, we perform the operations in order from left to right.
Similarly, we perform multiplications and divisions in order from left to right.

solution.p:
Perform the operations in order from left to right.
\blert{20-8}-5=\blert{12}-5=7
\blert{36 \div 6} \div 2 =\blert{6}\div 2=3

statement.p: What do the associative laws tell us?

answer.p: A sum or product of three or more terms can be callculated in any order.

statement.p: Which two operations are not associative?
In what order should we perform a string of additions and subtractions?

answer.p: In order from left to right.

subsection.title: Combined Operations
subsection.p: How should we simplify the expression 4+6 \cdot 2 ?
If we do the addition first, we get (\blert{4+6}) \cdot 2 = \blert{10} \cdot 2 = 20 If we do the multiplication first, we get 4+(\blert{6 \cdot 2}) = 4 + \blert{12} = 48
Which one is correct? In order to avoid confusion, we make the following agreement.

assemblage.p: Always perform multiplications and divisions before additions and subtractions.

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: In longer expressions, it can be helpful to group the expression into its terms before beginning. Terms are expressions separated by addition or subtraction symbols. We simplify each term before combining them.

ol.li: In Example 5, we do not start by adding 6+2. We must perform multiplications before additions.
We simplify 12 \div 3 \cdot 2 by performing the operations from left to right: \blert{12 \div 3} \cdot 2 = \blert{4} \cdot 2 = 8

subsection.title: Parentheses
subsection.p: What if the addition should come first in a particular calculation? In that case, we use parentheses to enclose the sum, like this: (4+6) \cdot 2

assemblage.p: Perform any operations inside parentheses first.

statement.p: Is it true that multiplications should be performed before divisions? Why or why not?

answer.p: Perform multiplications and divisions in order from left to right.
Perform any operations inside parentheses first.

statement.p: If there are no parentheses, in what order should we perform multiplications and divisions?

answer.p: In order from left to right.

subsection.title: Fraction Bars
subsection.p: Like parentheses, a fraction bar is a grouping device.

assemblage.p: Expressions that appear above or below a fraction bar should be simplified first.

solution.p: We begin by computing the sums above and below the fraction bar. Then we can reduce the fraction. Thus, \dfrac{24+6}{12+6} = \dfrac{30}{18}=\dfrac{5}{3}

statement.p: Besides parentheses, what other symbol serves as a grouping device?
When adding fractions, which should you do first: reduce each fraction, or find an LCD?

subsection.title: Summary
subsection.p: Combining all our guidelines for simplifying expressions, we state the rules for the order of operations.

ol.li: First, perform any operations that appear inside parentheses, or above or below a fraction bar.
Next, perform all multiplications and divisions in order from left to right.
Finally, perform all additions and subtractions in order from left to right.

subsection.title: Algebraic Expressions
subsection.p: The order of operations applies to variables as well as constants. For example, the expression 5+2x tells us to multiply x by 2, then add 5 to the result. Thus, to evaluate the expression for x=8 for example, we write \begin{align*} \text{For }x=\alert{8},~~~~~~~~~~5+2x \amp = 5+2(\alert{8}) \amp \amp \blert{\text{Multiply first.}}\\ \amp = 5+16=21 \end{align*}
